IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Improve health and quality of life in the community
IRS990.MissionDescription: Mile Bluff Medical Center, as a community health resource center, will serve in a leadership capacity to facilitate the delivery of health care and medical services, including care for the elderly and home care to the residents of and visitors to Juneau County and surrounding counties. As part of this mission, the Mile Bluff Medical Center intends to facilitate confidential delivery of quality health care in a professional and timely manner by maintaining dedicated, compassionate and well trained medical staff and employees; progressive, professional management; and modern equipment and facilities consistent with fiscally sound business practices.
IRS990.Description: Mile Bluff Medical Center leads delivery of healthcare to its region through over 700 associates which coordinate care to deliver patient care as an integrated unit. Mile Bluff Medical Center and its affiliates also work seamlessly to meet the needs of the communities they serve. Requirements of the IRS community benefit standard for tax-exempt organizations are integral to Mile Bluff Medical Center's larger charitable mission of improving health and quality of life. Specifically, Mile Bluff Medical Center is governed by an independent board including community leaders, consumer representatives, business experts and clinical healthcare experts. The Board has a history of commitment to acting with the highest integrity and has been proactively evaluating opportunities to voluntarily adopt governance best practices to ensure the organization continues to operate with the highest of integrity for the benefit of the community. Policies on confidentiality of patient and corporate information are reviewed annually as a component of mandatory education, and a confidentiality statement is signed annually by all employees and board members. Mile Bluff Medical Center's code of ethics/code of conduct is published in employee and physician handbooks, reviewed annually with all employees, and included in general orientation of all new employees.Mile Bluff Medical Center also makes medical care accessible to the entire community it serves. Mile Bluff Medical Center operates a full-time emergency room and provides emergency care regardless of ability to pay. Mile Bluff Medical Center provides clinical services needed to operate the Emergency Room and provides on-site emergency medical care and medical transportation services through an area ambulance service, and an onsite helipad. In addition, Mile Bluff Medical Center, through its integrated network of providers, provides non-emergency services to the community it serves. It makes these services accessible to the community through participation in government programs like Medicare and Medicaid and by offering assistance through their Financial assistance program. Mile Bluff Medical Center's Financial Assistance Policy provides discounted and free services to patients who lack the resources to be fully responsible for the health care they receive. The Financial Assistance Policy is designed to ensure the entire community served by Mile Bluff Medical Center has access to needed healthcare services. Eligibility for discounted or free services under the Financial Assistance Policy is based on income levels and family size. The Federal Policy Income Guidelines are used to determine levels of discounts. Applications for coverage under the program may be obtained at any Mile Bluff Medical Center patient registration area or by calling the Business Office Manager at (608)847-6161. Mile Bluff Medical Center maintains records to identify and monitor the level of care provided under the Financial Assistance program. These records include the amount of charges for services and supplies furnished, and the amount of discount applied. Mile Bluff Medical Center takes its mission to improve the health and quality of life of the people it serves a step further by reaching out to meet the broad health needs of the community. It strives to identify community needs beyond basic healthcare, then respond to them, aiming to make a positive, life-enhancing difference in the community. Contributing to Community Education: Mile Bluff Medical Center's Nursing staff and Home Health Agency Nurses participate in county wide community health fairs. These events provide information and guidelines to those in need of Medical information.Preventive Care a Priority: Mile Bluff Medical Center has taken steps to enhance preventive care for people of all ages by ensuring that those who come here for preventive care receive the screenings and recommendations appropriate to their personal and family history.The Medical Center maintains records to identify and monitor the level of charity care it provides. These records include the amount of charges foregone for services and supplies furnished under its charity care policy. The amounts of charges foregone for the year ended September 30, 2010 were $2,360,138. The estimated costs of the charges foregone, based upon an overall cost-to-charge ratio calculation, for the years ended September 30, 2010 were $1,200,000.In addition, the Medical Center provides services to other medically indigent patients under certain governmentreimbursed public aid programs. Such programs pay providers amounts which are less than established charges for the services provided to the recipients, and for some services the payments are less than the cost of rendering the services provided. The Medical Center also commits significant time and resources to endeavors and critical services which meet otherwise unfulfilled community needs. Many of these activities are sponsored with the knowledge that they will not be self-supporting or financially viable.

OtherLiabilities.Description: Fair value of interest rate swap agreement
Unsecured notes payable to residents of Terrace Heights

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Medical Center has adopted the provisions of FASB Accounting Standards Codification Topic ASC 740-10 (previously Financial Interpretation No. 48, Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes) on October 1, 2009. The implementation of this standard had no impact on the financial statements. As of both the date of adoption, and as of September 30, 2010, the unrecognized tax benefit accrual was zero. The Medical Center will recognize future accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits in income tax expense if incurred. The Medical Center is no longer subject to Federal and state tax examinations by tax authorities for years before 2006.
Decrease in fair value of interest rate swap agreement: -446110.
Temporarily restricted net assets released from restrictions : 69533.

Name.BusinessNameLine1: Mile Bluff Medical Ctr Home Health Care

Form990ScheduleHPartVI.IncomeBasedCriteria: Part I, Line 3c: In addition to providing free or discounted care based on Federal Poverty Guidelines, we review monthly income and expenses, held assets and liabilities, bank statements, taxes, etc. Being below, or at the 150% poverty guideline does not always accurately tell us a patient's ability to pay. A patient could be below 150%, but have substantial assets (real estate, vehicles, retirement fund). Conversely, a patient could be slightly over the 150%, but after reviewing all financial information, their ability to pay may be very limited. Offering discounts in these types of scenarios offers the patient a realistic payment, and reduces bad debt expense for Mile Bluff Medical Center.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.CostingMethodUsed: Part I, Line 7: Charity care expense was converted to cost on line 7a based on an overall cost to charge ratio addressing all patient segments. Unreimbursed Medicaid on line 7b was calculated using the costing methods to prepare the cost reports. Community health improvement services, health professions education, and cash and in-kind contributions to community groups, lines 7e, 7f, and 7i are reported based on actual expenses recorded in the organization's general ledger. The cost for subsidized health services reported on line 7g was determined using the Medicare cost report.Total community benefit expense as a percentage of total expenses is 12.6%.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.SubsidizedHealthServicesExpln: Part I, Line 7g: Costs of $1,664,212 were included in subsidized health services reported on line g. These are the costs to operate two rural health clinics.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.PercentOfTotalExpenseExpln: Part I, Line 7f: The amount of bad debt removed from total expenses to determine the percentage was $2,741,126.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.BadDebtFootnote: Part III, Line 4: The organization's bad debt expense was converted to cost using the cost to charge ratio derived from Worksheet 2.Before an account is classified as bad debt, all payments including self-pay, insurance, contractual allowances, and discounts are applied to the account. Accounts qualifying for financial assistance or charity care are not written off to bad debt. Payments on accounts that were written off to bad debt are listed as bad debt recoveries and reduce bad debt expense. Mile Bluff Medical Center does not refuse service to patients with bad debt.Mile Bluff Medical Center budgets for and monitors the level of charity care it provides. The organization does not limit charity care if the charity care exceeds the budgeted amount. The estimated amount of the organization's bad debt expense attributable to patients eligible under the organization's charity care policy is calculated based on an estimate of charity care to gross charges.Footnote to financial statements:The carrying amount of patient and resident receivables is reduced by a valuation allowance that reflects management's estimate of amounts that will not be collected from patients, residents, and third-party payors. Management reviews patient and resident receivables by payor class and applies percentages to determine estimated amounts that will not be collected from third parties under contractual agreements and amounts that will not be collected from patients and residents due to bad debts. Management considers historical write off and recovery information in determining the estimated bad debt provision. Management also reviews accounts to determine if classification as charity care is appropriate.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.ShortfallAsCommunityBenefit: Part III, Line 8: Mile Bluff Medical Center provides services to patients under the Medicare program knowing they will not recover all the costs associated with providing these services. Providing these services is essential to these patients and the community and increases their access to healthcare services. Therefore, the Medicare shortfall is considered a community benefit.Total revenue received from Medicare is the gross reimbursement plus settlement. Both total revenue received from Medicare and the Medicare allowable costs are reported from the Medicare Cost Report.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.DebtCollectionPolicy: Part III, Line 9b: To fulfill its mission of community service, the Medical Center provides care to patients and residents who meet certain criteria under its charity care policy without charge or at amounts less than its established rates. The Medical Center does not pursue any collection efforts of accounts for patients who are known to qualify or have qualified for charity care or financial assistance. Mile Bluff Medical Center tries to identify patients who are uninsured or under-insured at the time of registration or discharge. Charity care is offered to patients who are not eligible for public programs and who, after an investigation of the circumstances surrounding the patient's ability to pay, is determined by the Medical Center, to be unable to pay all or part of the hospital's normal billed charges.Prompt pay discounts are offered for patients who opt to pay the entire balance in one lump sum, providing the accounts are current. An account is considered current if the account is less than 120 days old. Monthly statements are sent to all patients. Patients with no coverage as well as accounts with balances after insurance payments (coinsurance, deductibles, copays), are worked on by a third party collection agency. Accounts that qualify for the charity care program are managed in house. Some accounts are written off in full. Some are awarded a 50% write-off, contingent on an agreement from the patient, that for every payment they make, the hospital will write off an equal amount. If, at any time, the patient stops making the payments as agreed upon, the patient is responsible for the entire amount and normal collection efforts will begin.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.NeedsAssessment: Part VI, Line 2: We use the following tools to assess health care needs of the communities we serve: (1) Patient exit questionnaires are distributed and reviewed; (2) Involvement in community groups such as Women's Health Initiative for Juneau County where we assess health needs based upon discussions and topics brought up by members of this group; (3) Analysis of data received from the WHA; and (4) Utilization of the Intelimed software program which allows us to analyze data from facilities comparable to ours.There were no new initiatives implemented as a result of discovering new unmet needs in our community in FY 2010.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.PatientEducationAssistance: Part VI, Line 3: Our Admissions staff identifies self pay patients at registration and patients who may qualify for financial assistance. Our business office staff then reviews our charity care policy with these patients, as well as any government programs we feel the patient may qualify for. Our charity care application is available to anyone who requests it. We do not currently post our charity care policy in our facilities. This is something we are looking at providing in the next fiscal year. The policy will be posted in our waiting rooms, emergency rooms, admissions areas, and charity care information will be provided on our monthly statements.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.CommunityInformation: Part VI, Line 4: Mile Bluff Medical Center is the only hospital in Juneau County. We serve a population of more than 55,000 residents in a five-county rural region. The nearest large hospitals are 60-70 miles away (LaCrosse and Madison). The medical center is the largest employer in the area. Farmers and small business owners make up the bulk of the work force. Uninsured and Medicaid recipients account for 25% of our total payor mix. Medicare patients account for 65% of our total payor mix. Average household income is $40,000/year. 10% of the local population lives below the poverty level.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.CommunityBuildingActivities: Part VI, Line 5: Community support activity reported on Part II, line 3 include training and drills for disaster readiness.The coalition building activity reported on Part II, line 6 includes organizing times for the public to walk and exercise at local schools.
Form990ScheduleHPartVI.OtherInformation: Part VI, Line 6: Mile Bluff Medical Center offers 40 beds in an acute care setting with state of the art technology and professional services. The hospital also has 2 60-bed nursing homes, 1 with a 12-bed community-based residential facility, 34 apartment complex retirement home, 3 clinics, 2 of which are rural health clinics, a dialysis center, and home health care. Many of our Board of Directors are neither employees nor contractors of the organization. Most work at, or operate, local businesses. To meet the needs of the community, the hospital extends medical staff privileges to all qualified, licensed physicians in the community. Surplus funds are reinvested in patient care and facility upgrades. We offer several education opportunities and health care services across our county throughout the course of the year at little to no cost. We average about 15 events a year. Some of the services provided are: cholesterol and blood pressure screenings, diabetic education, smoking cessation, grief and depression counseling, hearing loss screening, nutritional education, CPR classes, sibling and babysitting classes, exercise and well-being, skin checks, and classes dealing with cancer. We strongly encourage and recruit volunteers to help out at our hospital. Tasks vary from patient centered activities to simple clerical work.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: The organization's physicians are paid incentives based on the amount of volume they do. The charge amount of specific procedure codes performed by the physician is multiplied by a percentage to calculate the amount of the incentive. These incentives are paid out quarterly.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: A copy of the Form 990 is made available to the governing body before it is filed. The Form 990 is reviewed by the organization's CEO and CFO.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Each Director must disclose to the Board of Directors any duality of interest or possible conflict of interest whenever the duality or conflict pertains to a matter being considered by the Board. Any Director having duality of interest or conflict of interest on any matter must abstain from voting on the matter and is not counted in determining the quorum for the vote on the matter. In addition, the Director will not use his or her personal influence on the matter, but may briefly state his or her position on the matter and may answer pertinent questions from other Directors since his or her knowledge may be of great assistance. The minutes of the meeting involving any such situation must reflect that a disclosure was made, the abstention from voting, and the quorum situation. If a Director is uncertain as to whether he or she has a duality or conflict of interest which requires abstention, or if a Director asserts that another Director has such a duality or conflict, the Board, by majority vote of those present other than the Director having the possible conflict, will decide whether abstention is required. If so, the Director will be deemed to have abstained.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board of Directors determines the compensation for the CEO, CFO and key employees. Compensation is based on an annual review, which includes a performance evaluation, fair market value data, and comparability data based on other exempt hospitals. The process is completed annually, approved, and documented by the Board of Directors. The compensation process was last completed in FY2010.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The organization's governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements are not available to the public. However, financial information is available through the public disclosure copy of the 990.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 1a:
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Executive Committe consists of the Chairperson, as Chair, the Vice Chairperson, who is acting Chair when the Chairperson is absent, the Secretary, the Treasurer, and two other members of the Board of Directors. The Executive Committee has power to transact all regular business of the organization during the interim between the meetings of the Board of Directors, provided any action taken does not conflict with the policies and expressed wishes of the Board of Directors, and that it refers all matters of major importance to the Board of Directors.
